image.altText: A picture of a smiling man's face, attached to a wooden cross outside.

items.synopsis: At the Krasnopilske military cemetery in eastern Ukraine, one of the first things you hear is weeping — the women here all know each other, but they're bound together for devastating reasons.

title.children: Ukraine doesn't release its number of war casualties — at this cemetery, the real toll is on show

image.altText: Anthonty Albanese wearing a pink shirt and a wide brimmed hat surrounded by red flags and people in body paint.

items.synopsis: The prime minister will today announce when Australians will head to the polls to vote on whether to enshrine the Voice to Parliament in the constitution.

title.children: Prime minister to name date for Voice referendum

image.altText: Ozioma Onyekwere wears a pink shirt and Mary Ellen Kemister wears a striped shirt

items.synopsis: Permanent residency for aged care workers recruited from overseas is being fast-tracked by the government in a bid to address a jobs crisis in the sector, but at the same time, "high-quality" temporary workers are being made to leave the country.

title.children: Ozioma's heart lies in Australia, but a 'blanket rule' means she'll soon have to leave her job

image.altText: tall Gold Coast towers next to a beach

items.synopsis: Queensland is the top destination for those seeking a new adventure in their golden years, according to data from the Australian Bureau of Statistics.

title.children: Aussie retirees flocking to Queensland in record numbers, data reveals

image.altText: A man looks on.

items.synopsis: When Luis Rubiales grabbed Jenni Hermoso's face and kissed her on the lips during post-match celebrations at Stadium Australia, Spaniards were forced to pick a side, and start a national conversation about chauvinism.

title.children: 'Something deeply rotten': Soccer, chauvinism and the national conversation Spain had to have

image.altText: A woman with short dark hair stares at her reflection in a mirror, without smiling.

items.synopsis: Australia now has a 10-year road map on eating disorders. Here’s a look at what it includes.

title.children: What's in the National Eating Disorders Strategy?

image.altText: A composite image of five women, all smiling, with a soft green background.

items.synopsis: In any given year, at least 1 million Australian children and adults are living with an eating disorder. Four women have shared their experiences and hopes for a new road map on eating disorders.

title.children: 'Why don’t I look like that?' Four women speak out about their experiences of living with an eating disorder

image.altText: A young man sitting on his desk.

items.synopsis: The City of Gold Coast councillor accused of killing his stepfather could be released as early as next week, as lawyers call for him to be placed into protective custody while awaiting his bail hearing.

title.children: Gold Coast councillor Ryan Bayldon-Lumsden to seek early bail on murder charge

image.altText: A woman stands in an aisle of a grocery store and smiles at the camera

items.synopsis: Businesses struggling with record high diesel prices say they have no choice but to pass the increase on.

title.children: Soaring diesel prices could have customers paying more for 'everything'

image.altText: AI generated images of women from South Asia and East Asia

items.synopsis: AI-generated images of "beautiful" women from around the world have been going viral on TikTok. But some say they're based off stereotypes and can perpetuate colourist ideals.

title.children: Is there such thing as 'looking like' your ethnicity? These viral AI images think so

image.altText: Flowers grave Wagner Yevgeny Prigozhin after funeral

items.synopsis: A Kremlin spokesperson said funeral plans for the Wagner chief who died in a plane crash last week were up to relatives.

title.children: Mercenary chief Yevgeny Prigozhin buried on outskirts of St Petersburg

image.altText: A woman with long dark hair and glasses stares out the window while grasping a cup of tea.

items.synopsis: Analysis of Federal Court data has found 10 per cent of all forced bankruptcies across Australia are from strata levy debts.

title.children: Nicki owns a flat, but has gone into debt due to strata fees

image.altText: A man and woman, with their baby in a pram, looking at the ASX stock market boards in Sydney.

items.synopsis: A rally on Wall Street is likely to send Australian stocks higher, while a drop in the US monthly job openings fuels interest rate optimism. Follow the latest updates in our live blog.

title.children: ASX to rise ahead of monthly CPI indicator, Wall Street rallies

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Key US jobs data began approaching pre-pandemic levels in July, a sign of the sort of employment market cooling Federal Reserve officials hope can lower inflation without a sharp rise in the unemployment rate. The Labor Department's Job Openings and Labor Turnover Survey (JOLTS) showed 2.3 per cent of non-farm payroll workers quit their jobs in July, down from a rate as high as 3 per cent during the pandemic-driven "Great Resignation". The reading was the lowest since January 2021, when a wave of resignations was developing, and comparable to what was seen through 2018 and 2019 when a tight job market and low inflation coexisted. The hiring rate last month hit its lowest point since April 2020. Combined, the two data points suggested a drop in labor demand and an easing of hiring conditions, something the US central bank feels is necessary to continue lowering inflation and easing the pressure for wage hikes. The hope among policymakers is for that adjustment to happen without the sharp rise in unemployment that has accompanied prior Fed efforts to tame inflation with interest rate increases meant to slow the economy.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Key US jobs data boost Fed's soft-landing hopes

children.content: Key US jobs data began approaching pre-pandemic levels in July, a sign of the sort of employment market cooling Federal Reserve officials hope can lower inflation without a sharp rise in the unemployment rate.
The Labor Department's Job Openings and Labor Turnover Survey (JOLTS) showed 2.3 per cent of non-farm payroll workers quit their jobs in July,
down from a rate as high as 3 per cent during the pandemic-driven "Great Resignation"
The reading was the lowest since January 2021
, when a wave of resignations was developing, and comparable to what was seen through 2018 and 2019 when a tight job market and low inflation coexisted.
The hiring rate last month hit its lowest point since April 2020

Combined, the two data points suggested a drop in labor demand and an easing of hiring conditions, something the US central bank feels is necessary to continue lowering inflation and easing the pressure for wage hikes.

The hope among policymakers is for that adjustment to happen without the sharp rise in unemployment that has accompanied prior Fed efforts to tame inflation with interest rate increases meant to slow the economy.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: So the speech happened last night at ANU in Canberra and it was interrupted by a small group of protesters during the opening remarks. But Michele Bullock took it in her stride saying she was happy to see some activism still on a university campus. The key takeaways from her speech are: Climate change will require the RBA to reassess how best to control inflation A recent review of the RBA determined the bank's inflation target between 2-3 per cent remained suitable Uncertainty from extreme weather events could lead to higher inflation Read more from business reporter Kate Ainsworth .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ICYMI: incoming RBA governor Michele Bullock's first speech since being appointed

featuredLink.title: Protesters interrupt incoming RBA boss for wanting '140,000 people' to lose their jobs

children.content: So the speech happened last night at ANU in Canberra and it was interrupted by
a small group of protesters during the opening remarks.
But Michele Bullock took it in her stride saying she was happy to see some activism still on a university campus.
The
key takeaways
from her speech are:
Climate change will require the RBA to reassess how best to control inflation
A recent review of the RBA determined the bank's inflation target between 2-3 per cent remained suitable
Uncertainty from extreme weather events could lead to higher inflation
Read more from
business reporter
Kate Ainsworth

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The corporate watchdog Australian Securities & Investments Commission (ASIC) has put banks on notice to lift their game when it comes to helping customers who are experiencing financial hardship. ASIC Commissioner Danielle Press told ABC senior business correspondent Peter Ryan that banks could be fined for unethical, unlawful or uncompassionate behaviours. Here's the full interview.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Banks warned to treat their financially distressed customers better

featuredLink.title: Banks warned to treat their financially distressed customers better - ABC listen

children.content: The corporate watchdog Australian Securities
Investments Commission (ASIC) has put banks on notice to lift their game when it comes to helping customers who are experiencing financial hardship.
ASIC Commissioner
Danielle Press
told ABC senior business correspondent
Peter Ryan
that banks could be fined for unethical, unlawful or uncompassionate behaviours.
Here's the full interview.

image.altText: A close-up of a fire truck, with 'fire and rescue' written on red paint

items.synopsis: A 12-year-old boy is in custody after being found near the home by police.

title.children: Child charged with arson after allegedly starting blaze that destroyed Whitsundays home

image.altText: kelpie dog in a wheelchair in a grassy paddock

items.synopsis: The Australian kelpie lost the use of her hind legs in a farm accident six months ago, but thanks to a custom-made set of wheels, Ali is back at work doing what she loves.

title.children: Ali's new wheels a second chance to round up sheep, becoming a TikTok sensation along the way

image.altText: You see a man in a bright neon yellow rain jacket in a field holding a bunch of overgrown weeds.

items.synopsis: Experienced forager Diego Bonetto says safe foraging comes down to careful identification of plants and vigilant hygiene practices.

title.children: Foragers highlight food safety after parasite likely ingested from foraged greens extracted from woman's brain

image.altText: Two Brisbane Lions AFL players prepare to run onto the field.

items.synopsis: From an initial squad off 44 players, 22 will earn the honour of being selected in the final All-Australian Team. Cody Atkinson and Sean Lawson run the rule over who deserves to be in and who may miss out.

title.children: The AFL's All-Australian Team will be announced tonight. Who should make the cut?

image.altText: Three Brisbane Broncos NRL players embrace as they celebrate a try.

items.synopsis: The Penrith Panthers have a great chance at nabbing the minor premiership after Brisbane announced a completely revamped side to face a similarly unrecognisable Storm team in the last round of the season.

title.children: Broncos show little regard for NRL minor premiership, resting almost all their rep stars for final round

image.altText: A low Earth orbit satellite

items.synopsis: After the Black Summer fires, experts called for a way of detecting bushfires more rapidly, using satellites. But executing this idea faces challenges.

title.children: An audacious plan to rapidly detect bushfires from space appears to have hit a roadblock

image.altText: Archival image, wide-shot, of trees, beach and water on Banaba island, Kiribati.

items.synopsis: People from the remote Pacific Island of Banaba say they've been blindsided over an agreement to explore phosphate mining on the tiny atoll and Centrex, an Australian mining company, inked the exploration deal.

title.children: Mining forced most of Banaba's population to relocate. Now an Australian company plans to mine the island

image.altText: A bin catching on fire in the back of a garbage truck

items.synopsis: The use of lithium battery-powered products in New South Wales is increasing, and so too is the rise in house fires caused by them.

title.children: Toxic fumes from lithium battery-ignited fires can be deadly. Here's what you should do

image.altText: An Australian tennis player gets his racquet over on top of the ball to hit a forehand return.

items.synopsis: On a tough day for the Aussies at the US Open,  Chris O'Connell is the only winner so far, beating compatriot Max Purcell, while there are more injury troubles for veteran Jason Kubler.

title.children: O'Connell downs Purcell in all-Aussie US Open clash

image.altText: Madison is holding a binder and smiling.

items.synopsis: As cost-of-living pressures continue to climb, people are looking for creative ways to save. One method gaining popularity on social media is called "cash stuffing". It's a reinvention of the old envelope system our grandparents used to use, and it's bringing back the use of physical cash.

title.children: Madison says she'll never use her card full-time again after discovering 'cash stuffing'

image.altText: The inside of a darkened room with large cabinets in it illuminated by a dull blue light.

items.synopsis: A large, unassuming building in industrial Wollongong containing a torrent of personal information is a closely guarded data hub that its owners are happy to keep out of the spotlight.

title.children: These buildings hold your personal information under tight security and you wouldn't even notice them

image.altText: A lion stands on top of a car next to a man holding a torch.

items.synopsis: Footage shows the moment an adult lion was captured after escaping from a private vehicle amidst heavy traffic in the Pakistani city of Karachi.

title.children: Lion on the loose causes hours of panic wandering through busy traffic in Pakistan

image.altText: A surgeon operates in a theatre.

items.synopsis: Only one in five general surgeons in Australia is a woman but that number falls to just 16 per cent outside the big cities, according to new research.

title.children: Why female surgeons are less likely to live outside the big cities

image.altText: Wooden marionette and shadows.

items.synopsis: In the beginning, he was charming, gentle and caring — but after she and her two children moved in with him, everything changed. Coercive control was at the centre of their relationship — with a court in Hobart hearing from three other victims of the same man.

title.children: 'You used and abused these women as you pleased': Hugs in court as man jailed over repeated abuse

image.altText: An older woman with a dark grey bob and glasses speaks into a small microphone in front of a blue screen.

items.synopsis: Student protesters interrupt the beginning of a speech by incoming RBA governor Michele Bullock, taking issue with her past comment about needing to see the unemployment rate rise.

title.children: Protesters interrupt incoming RBA boss for wanting '140,000 people' to lose their jobs

image.altText: Photo of Tracy Sorensen, who has brown eyes and is smiling to the camera with faded green background

items.synopsis: When author Tracy Sorensen realised she didn't know much about her body parts that were affected by cancer, she found a unique way to learn — and write — about them.

title.children: Author Tracy Sorensen was dealing with cancer. So she turned her spleen into an 'anarcho communist'

image.altText: An elderly couple down a mall with the help of a younger woman.

items.synopsis: I've read the 300-odd pages of the Intergenerational Report pretty carefully and, with the exception of the section on climate change, I'm yet to find anything particularly alarming, writes Peter Martin.

title.children: Australia isn't quite facing the 'ageing time bomb' alarmist headlines would have you believe

image.altText: A white woman, a white man with down syndrome and another white man dance in loose fitting clothing on a stage.

items.synopsis: The 52-year-old choreographer and wheelchair user channelled her experience into an ode to vulnerability, which will open at Sydney Opera House this week before touring to Seoul.

title.children: Michelle transformed a distressing incident with the police into a world-class performance
